ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I further developed my critical reading skills and essay writing skills

I strengthened my critical thinking and literary analysis skills. I also learned how to more effectively engage in group discussions and synthesize multiple perspectives on and interpretations of the same work.
Close reading, incorporating literary criticism into my essays

I read a variety of texts from the time period that each had something different to contribute to the syllabus. As suggested by its name, this class teaches you where the conception of the "novel" comes from and how it has developed.

I developed a better understanding of the novel as a style of literature, and how it relates to other styles of literature that came before and after it. I learned how to engage with texts from the perspective of genre, and see how genre can change or impact the purpose and understanding of the story

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: fantastic book selection and strong assignments that help increase engagement. Weaknesses: none
Such a great course. The only downside was how much time we spent on Tristram Shandy: I wish we had dedicated more time to a different work instead
Strength is by far Professor Eccles! Shes the best. Our discussions were always productive, and our class got really close. Id say the one drawback was how long/dense some of the readings were.
The texts were very hit or miss for me, but they did each offer a lot of opportunity for engagement and discussion.

Strengths: Prof. Eccles is definitely a strength, she brings really interesting insights to class and offers a valuable perspective on the discussion. She also allows the discussion to flow naturally, though, and the students wind up leading their own class a lot of the time, which is interesting. The presentations by students on the supplementary readings each week fostered great discussion, and she has you write a letter every other week to your writing partner about what you've been reading and what your thoughts are, which I thought was a really unique part of the class and I really enjoyed getting to do those
Weaknesses: the reading list a little obscure, and there were so many texts on it that it forced us to cut discussion short on most of them, which was disappointing because it always felt like we'd only scratched the surface before we had to move on to the next text. Also, while Prof. Eccles gives really great feedback on papers, it takes her quite a while to get that feedback to you, so we didn't have grades/comments before the end of add/drop or our second paper, which would have been helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, the range of books in this course greatly expands how you view literature, and it is just a fun time overall
Absolutely. Our seminar discussions have changed the way I engage with readings, and I always left with several new ideas to research and think or write about.

Yes, I would, just to take a class with Prof. Eccles! Full disclosure: the readings are long and sometimes not super accessible when youre reading them by yourself. I would say, however, they become 1000% more interesting when you and your classmates and Prof. Eccles are talking about them in class! So make sure you are interested in the readings before committing. But I loved the class!
Yes! Professor Eccles is a wonderful professor.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially on who is interested in approaching literature from a non-traditional perspective. Just don't expect texts that you're already familiar with (or that you can find summaries for on the internet)
